Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated June 23, 1960, of the Kerala High Court in Second Appeal No. 103 1957.

A gift  Hiba  is the conferring of a right of property in something specific without an exchange  ewaz . The word Hiba literally means the donation of a thing from which the donee may derive a benefit. The transfer must be immediate and complete  tamlik-ul-ain  for the most essential ingredient of Hiba is the declaration I have given.

concepts.interpretation: Requires declaration (ijab), acceptance (qabul), and delivery of possession (qabza); immediate and complete transfer without consideration, distinguishing from sales.

issues.text: Is a gift by a husband to his minor wife and accepted on her behalf by her mother valid?

anchor.surface_text: This appeal by special leave by defendants Nos. 1 to 3 raises an important question under the Muhammadan Law, which may be stated thus Is a gift by a husband to his minor wife and accepted on her behalf by her mother valid P It has

holdings.reasoning_summary: Clear intention via registered deed handed to mother-in-law; possession delivered to her on behalf of minor wife who had attained discretion; no property guardian existed; supported by Hanafi analogies, istihsan, istislah, and precedents

holdings.text: A gift (Hiba) requires tender (ijab), acceptance (qabul), and delivery of possession (qabza)

precedents.citation: Mohammad Sadiq Ali Khan v. Fakhr Jahan 1

anchor.surface_text: In Mohammad Sadiq Ali Khan v. Fakhr Jahan 1 , it was held that even mutation of names is number necessary if the deed declares that possession is delivered and the deed is handed to the wife. A similar extension took place in cases of gifts by a guardian to his minor ward  Wilson Digest of Anglo-Muhammadan Law 6th Edn. p. 328 .

precedents.case_name: Mohammad Sadiq Ali Khan v Fakhr Jahan
precedents.cited_proposition: in cases where donor and donee reside together, an overt act is sufficient for gift between husband and wife; mutation not necessary if deed declares delivery of possession and is handed to wife
precedents.cited_holding: even mutation of names is number necessary if the deed declares that possession is delivered and the deed is handed to the wife

precedents.citation: Md. Abdul Ghani v. Mt. Fakhr Jahan  1

anchor.surface_text: In Md. Abdul Ghani v. Mt. Fakhr Jahan  1 , it was held by the Judicial Committee as follows In companysidering what is the Mohammaden Law on the subject of gift intervivos their Lordships have to bear in mind that when the old and admittedly authoritative texts of Mohammedan law were promulgated there were number in the companytemplation of any one any Tran sfer of Property Acts, any Registration Acts, any Revenue Courts to record transfers of the possession of land, or any zamindari estates large or small, and that it companyld number have been intended to lay down for all time what should alone be the evidence that titles to lands had passed.

precedents.case_name: Md Abdul Ghani v Mt Fakhr Jahan
precedents.cited_proposition: Mohammedan law of gifts aims to prevent disputes on intention to pass title; handing over and acceptance is good evidence; old texts did not contemplate registration etc
precedents.cited_holding: the object of the Mohammedan law as to gifts apparently was to prevent disputes as to whether the donor and the donee intended at the time that the title to the property should pass from the donor to the donee and that the handing over by the donor and the acceptance by the donee of the property should be good evidence that the property had been given by the donor and had- been accepted by the donee as a gift

precedents.citation: Mahamad Sadiq Ali Khan v. Fakhr Jahan Begum 2

anchor.surface_text: Later in Mahamad Sadiq Ali Khan v. Fakhr Jahan Begum 2 , it was held by the Privy Council that at least between husband and wife Muhammadan law did number require an actual vacation by the husband and an actual taking possession by the wife. In the opinion of the Judicial Committee the declaration made by the husband followed by the handing over of the deed was sufficient to establish the transfer of possession.

precedents.case_name: Mahamad Sadiq Ali Khan v Fakhr Jahan Begum
precedents.cited_proposition: between husband and wife, no need for actual vacation by husband and taking possession by wife; declaration and handing over of deed sufficient
precedents.cited_holding: at least between husband and wife Muhammadan law did number require an actual vacation by the husband and an actual taking possession by the wife. In the opinion of the Judicial Committee the declaration made by the husband followed by the handing over of the deed was sufficient to establish the transfer of possession

precedents.citation: Nabi Sab v. Papiah and ors.  1

anchor.surface_text: In Nabi Sab v. Papiah and ors.  1  it was held that gift did number necessarily fail merely because possession was number handed over to the minors father or guardian and the donor companyld numberinate a person to accept the gift on behalf of the minor. It was pointed out that the Muhammadan law if gifts, though strict, companyld number be taken to be made up of unmeaning technicalities.

precedents.cited_proposition: gift does not necessarily fail if possession not handed to minor's father or guardian; donor can nominate person to accept on behalf of minor; law not unmeaning technicalities
precedents.cited_holding: gift did number necessarily fail merely because possession was number handed over to the minors father or guardian and the donor companyld numberinate a person to accept the gift on behalf of the minor

anchor.surface_text: A similar view was expressed in Nauab Ian v. Safiur Rehman 2 . These cases were followed recently in Munni Bai and anr. v. Abdul Gani 3 , where it was held that when a document embodying the intention of the donor was delivered to the minor possessing discretion and accepted by her it amounted to acceptance of gift.

precedents.cited_proposition: similar view to Nabi Sab on gifts to minors without strict possession delivery

precedents.citation: Munni Bai and anr. v. Abdul Gani 3

anchor.surface_text: These cases were followed recently in Munni Bai and anr. v. Abdul Gani 3 , where it was held that when a document embodying the intention of the donor was delivered to the minor possessing discretion and accepted by her it amounted to acceptance of gift. It was further pointed out that all that was needed was that the donor must evince an immediate and bona fide intention to make the gift and to companyplete it by some significant overt act.

precedents.cited_proposition: delivery of document to minor with discretion who accepts amounts to acceptance; donor must show immediate bona fide intention and complete by overt act
precedents.cited_holding: when a document embodying the intention of the donor was delivered to the minor possessing discretion and accepted by her it amounted to acceptance of gift

precedents.case_name: Suna Mia v S A S Pillai
precedents.cited_proposition: gift to minor through mother invalid
precedents.cited_holding: gift to a minor through the mother was companysidered invalid

precedents.citation: Musa Miya and anr. v. Kadar Bux 1

anchor.surface_text: and Musa Miya and anr. v. Kadar Bux 1 , where a gift by a grandfather to his minor grandsons when the father was alive, without delivery of possession to the father, was held to be invalid. Both these cases involve gifts in favour of minors whose fathers were alive and companypetent.

precedents.cited_proposition: gift by grandfather to minor grandsons invalid without delivery to father when father alive
precedents.cited_holding: a gift by a grandfather to his minor grandsons when the father was alive, without delivery of possession to the father, was held to be invalid
